title.value: Source-free Domain Adaptation Requires Penalized Diversity
title.justification: This is the title as given at the beginning of the paper.
title.quote: Source-free Domain Adaptation Requires Penalized Diversity

extractions.description: The paper proposes a novel unsupervised source-free domain adaptation (SFDA) algorithm named Penalized Diversity (PD). PD enhances representational diversity through the use of separate feature extractors with distinct backbone architectures (DBA). Furthermore, the paper introduces the Weak Hypothesis Penalization (WHP) regularizer to mitigate the amplification of weak hypotheses. The effectiveness of PD is demonstrated empirically in natural, synthetic, and medical domains under different distributional shifts.

type.justification: The paper conducts empirical comparisons and experiments on multiple datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of their proposed SFDA algorithm.
type.quote: Empirical results on natural, synthetic, and medical domains demonstrate the effectiveness of PD under different distributional shifts.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on domain adaptation, specifically source-free domain adaptation.
name.quote: Source-free domain adaptation (SFDA) was introduced to address knowledge transfer between different domains in the absence of source data, thus, increasing data privacy.

name.justification: The paper discusses unsupervised setting of SFDA where no labeled target data is available.
name.quote: We encourage diversity among ensemble members in an unsupervised source-free domain adaptation setting where no labeled target data is available.

name.justification: The paper aims to address covariate shift through domain adaptation techniques.
name.quote: Our work proposes Penalized Diversity (PD) where the synergy of DBA and WHP is applied to unsupervised source-free domain adaptation for covariate shift.

name.justification: The paper also proposes techniques to handle label distribution shift in the context of SFDA.
name.quote: We further extend PD to address the label distribution shift by introducing a weighted MI maximization based on estimation over target distribution.

name.justification: The paper presents Penalized Diversity (PD) as its novel contribution to the field.
name.quote: we propose a novel unsupervised SFDA algorithm that promotes representational diversity through the use of separate feature extractors with Distinct Backbone Architectures (DBA).

is_contributed.justification: Penalized Diversity (PD) is introduced as a new contribution in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: we propose a novel unsupervised SFDA algorithm that promotes representational diversity through the use of separate feature extractors with Distinct Backbone Architectures (DBA).

is_executed.justification: Experiments with PD were conducted during the study to evaluate its effectiveness.
is_executed.quote: Empirical results on natural, synthetic, and medical domains demonstrate the effectiveness of PD under different distributional shifts.

is_compared.justification: PD is compared with several baseline models as part of the study's empirical results to demonstrate its effectiveness.
is_compared.quote: we propose a novel unsupervised SFDA algorithm that promotes representational diversity through the use of separate feature extractors with Distinct Backbone Architectures (DBA).

referenced_paper_title.justification: PD is the primary novel contribution of this paper and does not reference any prior work for its introduction.

name.justification: The dataset Office-31 is used in the experiments.
name.quote: Office-31 dataset includes three domains that share a set of 31 classes; Amazon (A), DSLR (D), and Webcam (W).

referenced_paper_title.value: Adapting visual category models to new domains
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the title of the reference paper where Office-31 dataset is originally introduced.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Saenko, K.; Kulis, B.; Fritz, M.; and Darrell, T. 2010. Adapting visual category models to new domains. In European conference on computer vision, 213–226. Springer.

name.justification: The dataset Office-Home is used in the experiments.
name.quote: Office-Home has four domains, each having 65 classes; Artistic images (AR), Clip art (CL), Product images (PR), and Real-World images (RW).

referenced_paper_title.value: Deep hashing network for unsupervised domain adaptation
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the title of the reference paper where Office-Home dataset is originally introduced.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Venkateswara, H.; Eusebio, J.; Chakraborty, S.; and Panchanathan, S. 2017. Deep hashing network for unsupervised domain adaptation. In Proceedings of the IEEE conference on computer vision and pattern recognition, 5018–5027.

name.justification: The dataset VisDA-C is used in the experiments.
name.quote: VisDA-C has 12 classes with synthetic images in the source domain and real images in the target domain.

referenced_paper_title.value: Visda: A synthetic-to-real benchmark for visual domain adaptation
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the title of the reference paper where VisDA-C dataset is originally introduced.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Peng, X.; Usman, B.; Kaushik, N.; Wang, D.; Hoffman, J.; and Saenko, K. 2018. Visda: A synthetic-to-real benchmark for visual domain adaptation. In Proceedings of the IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition Workshops, 2021–2026.

name.justification: The dataset LIDC is used in the experiments.
name.quote: LIDC dataset. Office-Home has four domains, each having 65 classes; Artistic images (AR), Clip art (CL), Product images (PR), and Real-World images (RW).

referenced_paper_title.value: The lung image database consortium (LIDC) and image database resource initiative (IDRI): a completed reference database of lung nodules on CT scans

referenced_paper_title.quote: Armato III, S. G.; McLennan, G.; Bidaut, L.; McNitt-Gray, M. F.; Meyer, C. R.; Reeves, A. P.; Zhao, B.; Aberle, D. R.; Henschke, C. I.; Hoffman, E. A.; et al. 2011. name.justification: The dataset MNIST is used in the experiments.
name.quote: for the label shift, we consider MNIST (M)

referenced_paper_title.quote: LeCun, Y.; Bottou, L.; Bengio, Y.; and Haffner, P. 1998. Gradient-based learning applied to document recognition. Proceedings of the IEEE, 86(11): 2278–2324.

name.quote: for the label shift, we consider MNIST-M (N)

referenced_paper_title.quote: Ganin, Y.; Ustinova, E.; Ajakan, H.; Germain, P.; Larochelle, H.; Laviolette, F.; Marchand, M.; and Lempitsky, V. 2016. Domain-adversarial training of neural networks. The journal of machine learning research, 17(1): 2096–2030.

name.quote: For the experiments on label shift, we consider synthetic digit datasets–MNIST (M), MNIST-M (N), and USPS (U).

name.justification: Several components and configurations in the paper align with the use of PyTorch.
name.quote: The code base of PD is built upon SHOT
